archimate:ArchimateDiagramModel.name: Stakeholders
archimate:ArchimateDiagramModel.documentation:
Stakeholders in TOGAF Architecture Vision A Stakeholder is any person, group, or organization that: • Has interests, concerns, or influence in the architecture. • Can affect or be affected by the outcomes of the architecture. • May provide requirements, approval, or support for architectural decisions.
Purpose of Identifying Stakeholders in Phase A:
• To understand expectations and align the architecture vision accordingly. • To capture concerns that must be addressed in the architecture. • To engage and communicate effectively throughout the ADM cycle. • To define success from various perspectives. • To help prioritize architecture decisions and trade-offs.
Typical Stakeholders in Architecture Vision:
Stakeholder Role->Description->Concerns Executive Sponsor->Provides funding and strategic direction->ROI, risk, business alignment Business Owner->Owns the business process or capability->Functionality, performance, efficiency End Users->Will use the solution->Usability, access, training IT Leadership (CIO, CTO)->Owns IT strategy and governance->Technology fit, future-proofing, cost Security Officer->Oversees compliance and risk->Privacy, threat protection, regulations Project Manager->Delivers the project->Timeline, scope, resources Data Owner/Architect ->Manages data and its use->Data quality, integration, lifecycle Operations/Support->Will maintain the solution ->Stability, manageability, downtime Regulators / Legal->Ensure compliance with laws->Risk, compliance, audit trails
Key Activities Involving Stakeholders in Phase A
1. Identify Stakeholders: o Use org charts, governance structures, or business units. 2. Analyze Their Concerns: o Use the Stakeholder Map or Influence-Interest Matrix. 3. Document Requirements: o Capture what they care about: goals, risks, KPIs, constraints. 4. Engage Them: o Tailor communication based on their role and influence. 5. Address in Architecture Vision Document: o Include stakeholder names, roles, concerns, and engagement strategy.
Tools You Can Use
• Stakeholder Map (TOGAF technique): Plots stakeholders by influence vs. interest. • Architecture Requirements Specification: Captures their needs. • Business Scenarios: Describe real-life stakeholder-driven situations.
Example: Stakeholder Entry (TOGAF-style)
Name->Role->Influence->Concerns->Engagement Approach Jane Doe-> CIO->High->Cloud readiness, security ->Weekly briefings John Smith->Operations Lead->Medium ->Downtime, monitoring->Review support model Sarah Green->Legal/Compliance->Low->Data protection, audit->Monthly compliance check-ins
